Rob, can you clarify what you mean when you say that keeping the complete g=
eneration history seems to be the root of the problem?  Are you saying that=
 something in the system that keeps a history is causing the memory to buil=
d up?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Rob Marsden <rob@...> wrote:
>
> I=
 have an application built around NEAT, that runs well and optimises as 
> =
planned, but it never achieves its target because I always get an 
> alloca=
tion exception.
> 
> The generated network isn't large. It has 7 inputs and=
 1 output and 
> usually around 3 or 4 hidden nodes, but the program still =
runs out of 
> memory on 32bit Windows, with 4GB of RAM. Task Manager shows=
 the slow 
> but inexorable increase in memory size. The limit is usually h=
it around 
> 10,000 generations. It sounds a lot but tests on random Out-of=
-Sample 
> data, whenever there is an improvement in performance would sugg=
est that 
> we haven't yet reached over-fitting.
> 
> So... is there anythi=
ng I can do to avoid the need to keep the complete 
> generation history, w=
hich seems to be the root of the problem.
> 
> This is a different problem =
to that I cited in my message of 13-Jan-2011.
> 
> -- 
> Rob Marsden
> Gist=
ix (Northern) Limited
